title: NAME': URL
wird: FANTOOSH (adj): owerdressed; flashy, fancy, ornate. ◇ Ye dinna think this jaiket is a bittie fantoosh, div ye? Origin: unner influence o Modren English dialect ‘fanty-sheeny’, frae Italians ‘fantoccino’ a puppet
REGISTRATE (ptp): registered. ◇ Aa colleages maun be registrate for the event by the end o the week. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘registrat’, Latin ‘registratus’, ptp o ‘registrare’
REMEID (n): remedy, redress. ◇ Hiv ye considert a herbal remeid? Origin: Aulder Scots ‘remed’, Anglo-Norman ‘remeide’, Anglo-Norman, Middle French ‘remede’. Also a verb
NETWARK (n): network. ◇ A new pipe netwark inbrocht watter tae the hoose. ◇ The netwark is doun sae we canna send ony emails. Origin: calque on Modren English ‘network’ (Scots ‘net’ + Scots ‘wark’)

ASSOCIATE (v, ptp): associate(d): ◇ In Austrailie antimony is whiles fund associate wi gowd. ◇ She haes been associate wi the project frae the first. Origin (ptp): Aulder Scots ‘associat’, Latin ‘associātus’
CONFORM TAE/TIL (idiom): in accordance with. ◇ The app haes been designed an biggit conform tae GDPR legislation. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘conform(e)’, Latin ‘conformis’
SECRETAR (n): secretary. ◇ Please contact the course secretar for mair information. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘secretare’, French ‘secrétaire’
ELEMENTAR (adj): basic, elemental, elementary. ◇ The physics course wis a elementar ane. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘elementa(i)r’, Middle French ‘elementaire’, Latin ‘elementārius’
DASK (n): desk, seat, church pew. ◇ The dask wis made o mahogany. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘dask(e)’, Middle English ‘deske’

FASH (v): irritate; tak trouble ower; vex; fret. ◇ Dinna fash me wi your girnin! ◇ I wis sair fasht at the thocht o the job interview. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘fas(c)h’, Middle French ‘faschier’. Also a noun

CONTEMPORAR (adj): contemporary. Origin: aiblins a analogy on Modren English ‘contemporary’ wi Scots ‘ordinar’, ‘elementar’ etc. The mak in Aulder Scots wis ‘contemporane’ (c1420), frae the Latin ‘contemporāneus’
JALOUSE (v): suspect; suppose, surmise. ◇ I jaloused I’d better haud ma tongue! ◇ I’m jalousin a server reboot micht be required. Origin: Late Middle Scots ‘jalous(e)’, French ‘jalouser’
FITBA (n): football. ◇ Ar ye gaun tae the fitba the morn? Origin: Aulder Scots ‘futebal(l)’, ‘fuitbal’, ‘futbaw’
RAIVELT (adj): tangelt, confused; ramblin, deleerit. ‘Fillin oot that tax return haed me fair raivelt.’ Origin: frae Aulder Scots verb ‘ravel’, Dutch ‘ravelen’, ‘rafelen’, tae tangle, frizz oot

SCUNNER (n): a feelin o disgust, laith; a person or thing that causes disgust or laith. ◇ It fairly gart me scunner ◇ He teuk a richt scunner at hivin tae wirk on the Sunday. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘scunner’, ‘skunner’, o unkent origin. Also a verb
SWAIDEN (n): Sweden. Origin: Middle Laich German, Middle Dutch ‘Sweden’
DICHT (v): clean, sweep, dust. ◇ Mind an dicht the bunker efter ye’r duin keukin. Aulder Scots ‘dicht’, ‘dycht’, Auld English ‘dihtan’. Also a noun
DELEERIT (adj): delirious, mad. ◇ She wis deleerit wi the fivver. Origin: Middle French ‘delirer’, Latin ‘dēlīrāre’ tae be mad
TIMEOUS (adj): timely. ◇ Rent maun be peyed in a timeous mainer. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘tymous’ (Scots ‘time’ + ‘ous’ adj-makkin endin)
CIRCUMVENE (v): circumvent. ◇ He wis fund tae hiv circumvened regulations. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘circumvene’, Middle French ‘circonvenir’, Latin ‘circumvenīre’
GLAIKIT (adj): stupit, fuil, thochtless. ◇ He’s a bittie glaikit leukin ◇ Dinna be a glaikit gowk, min! Origin: Aulder Scots ‘gla(i)kit’, o unkent origin
PROPONE (v): propose. ◇ Jamie proponed a motion tae the comatee. Origin: Aulder Scots ‘propone’; Laitin ‘prōpōnere’
